This game is a pretty standard example of how to milk a game for all it is worth using already existing assets.  I was an original player from back when the game was owned and run by Real Time Worlds (R.I.P) and published by EA. I was one of the first batch of players to play APB Reloaded during the closed beta period. After open beta is began it's continuous downward spiral.  Pros - Customization, it's nearly unmatched in the options for customizations  Cons - Poor community and lack of in-game moderating; griefers, hackers and inappropriate behavior that isn't punished. - Dominated by in-game microtransaction system; you'll rarely find people that play consistently who don't spend money in some form. It's not impossible to play without paying, takes a noticeable amount of time for it to be worth it. - Unoptimized. - Poor matchmaking; back during closed beta there weren't districts that were divided by 'threat level', so often times higher ranked players would get matched against many more people than were in their group. I consider that a step up to what is currently in the game. - Poor spawn system; pretty easy to push on a spawn so the enemy spawns farther away, and car spawners have completely ruined the dynamic of the game.

APB capitalizes on customization, great built-in design tools with lots of stuff to unlock and lots of skimpy non-clothing available for your female avatar's unproportionate â¥â¥â¥. Even though unsubscribed players are limited in how many design elements they can have on each peice of clothing or each vehicle, it still feels functional and fun. Hanging around the social district and seeing the hilariously creative outfits that players design is the most entertaining part of APB. Giving myself a back tattoo that said 'â¥â¥â¥â¥ASS' for all to see provided me with deep satisfaction.  Although the matchmaking and missions are fluid, innovative and fun, the sub-par combat and driving mechanics don't provide a sturdy foundation for all of this glorious and limitless customization to stand on, and it is reflected by its ever-crumbling playerbase.   Play long enough and your 'threat' level increases, putting you at a different matchmaking level to keep games fair and balanced, while at the same time isolating you from an exponentially larger part of the player pool with each rise in threat level. Before long I had reached the highest threat level, and was rewarded with a whopping 2 possible opponents that were currently online to play against. Nice. The most proposed solutions to lowering your threat level to again have fun with the game are to 'lose on purpose' or 'create a new character'... What? Seriously?  I'd like to see customization like this in the next stab at an online GTA-style open world game. APB definitely layed the groundwork for a matchmaking method that keeps everyone in the same world while simultaneously pitting groups of players against eachother. You'll often see fights between other teams going on right next to you.   Cool game overall, although the most fun to be had is in the customization menus and not in playing the game itself.

(For all of you looking at my 600 hours, I actually have 1000+).  Let me begin by saying that this is a one-of-a-kind MMO that I fell in love with the first time I was allowed into the closed beta. The games character customization blew me away, and quickly became my favorite part of the game, and to this day is the only thing I genuinely care about in terms of APB's overall content.   Combat is a different story. I can't even consider it to be combat much more than I consider it to be dancing. There's just a huge learning curve to this game. Back in the day, people use to jump and snipe. It was the most stupidest thing ever designed into a shooter. The game feels to be a bit ridiculous sometimes, that I just up and quit after about an hour. Along with that, I have a short list of complaints in my head with this game, and I'll just point have you read them here.   1: The community can be sort of â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ to new players. Even I at once would badger these 13 year old kids who barely found out what a microphone was, but I learned that it didn't help with anything, except maybe my ego. There are so many new players who just get put down by all the grizzled veterans that they see no reason to continue playing this god-forsaken game, and they would be pulling a smart move. There is a huge lack of motivation to stay in the game, unless of course you meet certain people that you can have a good time with. Even then however, the game makes it very hard to maintain a positive attitude.  #2: I use to part of a team of testers known back in the day as SPCI. It was a group picked by individuals who cared for the game, and also its testers. I admit I didn't do as much as others, but I was there when it came to the problems we faced. For one, whenever an upcoming patch needed testing, sometimes we were limited to only a day to do it. Now for most people, they couldn't test every day of the week, even me. Whoever could took a huge load of work. Once bugs and critical elements were reported, we'd expect G1 to be on top of these reports and fix them. This never ever happened in my experience. Sometimes these bugs wouldn't be addressed for months, sometimes never. It was this lack of action that made a lot of us question if what we were even doing was being appreciated. Eventually it all fell apart. Now there is a new team, whom I don't know, that either care about the game, or just want in on the upcoming content. In layman's terms, the new team to me feels like a bunch of complacant slaves who just want to have some 'imaginary' form of authority in the APB community. So yeah, G1 just needed people to test the game so that they could say they have a test team, and that's it. So far, they don't seem to care.   #3: This game is filled with people who use third-party software to get an advantage in the game (wallhacks, aimbots, etc). Not a single day goes by where I can play and all the opposing players play legit. Most of the time you can tell when your playing excellent players, sometimes it's a very thin line between legit and illegit. It's this thin line that makes people 'hackusate' even legit people, and it even gets legits banned. And even when the illegitimates get banned, there's no preventing them from being able to reroll. They'll just come back to rage-hack and continue being their immoral selves.   #4: This game will bring out the worst in you. It doesn't matter how much willpower you have, how much of a paragon/angel you are. This game will break you, no question. Most of the time, it's this reason people result in becoming illegitimates, because they either want to â¥â¥â¥â¥ on people, or because they don't want to spend the time to get better at something, and will use shortcuts to get their way. For people like me, who take it day by day, it is a struggle we endure for reasons even we don't really know. Maybe we hope for a day when the game will become what we always dreamed it to be. Maybe it's because we invested so much of our time into this game, we can't bare to let it go. The game has introduced me to some really good people, some of whom are good friends that I've known for years now. It's people like them that I wish filled the game, but sadly, the game is full of â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥s, give or take a few.   #5: The Grind is very VERY real in this game. It is literally a requirement that you have premium from the get-go if you even want to finish this game in a relatively quick amount of time, and unless you like me, who wants to spend nearly 600 hours of gametime getting to R195, your gonna want premium. I have a 1000+ hours on my main character, and he's only 246 at the moment. In the near future, when contacts need even more repect points from you, I might just die of old age.  #6: Teamwork is something that people in this game ignore, which is funny, because it is literally the only thing that wins matches. Playing with a bunch of randoms does not help you in the slightest. Playing with people you know, people your on a voice chat with, is going to win you more games than just immitating a headless chicken (literally running in like a moron, with no strategic plan). So if your going to play this game, make friends fast, or get friends to play with you, so that you can get somewhere rather than nowhere.   In conclusion, this game has a great concept, but it's maintained by a bad company, who's only reason for buying it was to milk the living crap out of it. You'll notice really quick that this game has very little content push, and more flashy â¥â¥â¥â¥ with an expensive price tag on all of it. The clothes I like, but the guns and cars are G1's main source of income. Sometimes I wonder what it would have been like had this game gone back to subscription based playing. I'd compare it to FFXIV, and say that more content would be added rather than ARMAS market items. In a way, I probably would have done subsciption over F2P. But it was never my call to begin with, so for now, I just go with the flow.   My score - 2/5   I still have high hopes for APB, but until then, I am not going to recommend it because it's not fun once the raging begins. If your really willing to punish yourself, learn from your mistakes, and learn to laugh at them as well, because your going in for one hell of a rollercoaster ride.   Word of warning: Be prepared to get â¥â¥â¥â¥ on when you play.   On a side note, they should add some PVE to this game. Would help me relax a bit.  Along with that, enforcer activities (raiding a den, gathering intel, arresting drug dealers, etc.)

Have you ever had a moment in your life where you're excited and ready to go? Starting APB was like that for me. I made my character, grabbed a gun, and went out into the world of gang violence.  Much like real gang violence, I was repeatedly brought low by people who bought better weapons than I could, could use the same weapons I had to better effect, and was matched up in a 'fair' fight against people who were like gods to me as an ant. even my car could best be described as a thin plastic shell around a chunk of explosive that functioned as an engine. Within 16 hours of gameplay, I had made every possible worst decision, from choosing a shotgun with the spread the size of a small house, to attempting any sort of PvP at all when close-quarters fighting meant gangbangers instantly ending my life repeatedly with SMGs and sniper rifles, while assault rifles were used to pick opponents off from 100 meters away. Any attempt at buying improved weaponry to escape the hellish catch-22 of ranking up to get new weapons was met with a paywall, and those who bought these rank-exempt weapons were unto demigods in their own right, as these 'same but different' weapons had the characteristics of their real life counterparts. Which, of course, meant they could actually kill you, unlike the peashooters and feather guns regular players are given. All in all, it's the standard Korean MMO pay-to-win format, but with guns and cars. Good if you need to be humbled or have the reflexes of a supercomputer.

I love crafting systems. Man, do I ever love good crafting systems in game. And what better then a game about the post apocolyse to really shine in this department? There is nothing quite as rewarding as savaging through mounds of garbage, collecting various long rusted do-dads, and long forgotten whats-its to make various deadly weapons to gut, barrage, or otherwise eviscerate various pus drooling mutants.  Okay, so the crafting is still varily limited. But compared to most MMORPGS it is still rather 'up there' on the scale of awesome. Combine that with real time FPS combat (which still boils down to a-typical pulling and grinding, admitably) and you got yourself some fun times.  The game is rather graphic intensive, but after kicking the graphics down even my laptop with it's outdated drivers and such was capable of running it releatively smoothly. Grab a friend, get your horse and hit the waste! It's time to launch your career as a down and dirty, gun toting scavager!

If there was a fallout online, and it had a massive dump, this game would be that dump.   Good community, once you reach the areas they hang out in. When you start, the game will put you clean off and you may very well quit. This game is an MMO. If that doesn't tell you what you should expect, probably stay away. If you like dying over and over again, this might be the game for you. I don't, which is why I'm glad I didn't pay for this. Frankly, this is not a review of the game so much as it is of the genre and the community. If you're the kind of person who can keep interest in this sort of thing long enough to get good, my review should mean nothing to you.  As for the rest? The people like me who joined too late/couldn't get the hang of it, and were thus deprived of all the fun this game had to offer? Well, if you're like me, you got interested in this based on style, color, and rampant, light-hearted brutality. You can find all that, plus a single-player or co-op environment that wants you to experience it, in the Saint's Row series. Saint's Row the Third and Saint's Row IV in particular are the closest to what I wanted out of APB. And go ahead and get the full package for the games as well, if you can. Having a tank right out of the tutorial sequence was EXTREMELY helpful and fun in 3.

If you enjoy large-world games this may be one for you. The crafting system is large and complex and the dusty plains provide a very fitting frame for the story. There's the option of going for missions or crafting as you level up, either way will make your character progress as you play. The GUI was daunting at first but after a few hours it felt more comfortable to use - but never easy or intuitive. As it stands now I'm on the verge of putting real money into the game, since I feel the developers have created a world that pulls me where other post-apocalyptic games have had a plastic, artificial feel to them. If you enjoy exploration and crafting, definitely try out this free to play version at the very least!

From what I remember you're stuck being a gruff looking human and the only customization after making your character is expensive clothing at overcrowded stores. This game is simply terrible. The matchmaking sucks (newbies always get paired against veterans), the gear is temporary unless you shell out real money for it, the game won't leave you alone about upgrading to a premium account, and the hit locations are meaningless (you can snipe someone in the foot and it'll technically count as a headshot if they don't have armor). On top of that, botters are rampant throughout the entire game. Most everyone I've played against has at least an aim-bot and/or trigger-bot because they aren't good enough to actually play the game without hacks. The missions are totally bland, too. Every single one basically boils down to whoever can get to the objective location first, and then it's a camp-fest while waiting to murder the entire team challenging the same location.  The bottom line is that APB: Reloaded looked like a good idea on paper, but the execution is horrendous. The anti-cheat system is basically non-existent, as the engine believes botters to be players with pin-point precision (which, in reality, is virtually impossible). With no reliable way to control the cheaters in the community, there's really no point in playing the game at all unless you're with friends. Then you all can have a good laugh at how bad the game is. Skip it.

Fallen Earth is a very fun and unique game, it has a lot of features such as mining rocks and scavaging in rubbish piles...with the copper you mine from rocks you can craft into bullets. You can also lvl up geometry skill which will allow you to mine higher lvl rocks and get more resorces from them, as far as pvp goes i have yet to try it out. I find that melee is a good skill to start lvling up right away because it can become handy later on, also the quest system is nice filled with different varieties and you never feel as if you have done the same quest more that twice.The map is HUGE and would take hours to explore and going out past a certain point you will find that enemies will get tougher very quickly which will force you to lvl up before exploring more which is good because when you die from a hard enemy and then go lvl up a little bit when you go back to that same enemy you feel like you are getting stronger and making progress towards you'r character. I very much enjoy a few hours a day of fallen earth and would easily give it an 8/10 for mmo standards. I have not seen many fps open world mmorpg's around and this is quite the package if you are looking for a game like this.
If your waiting for GTA V to come out for the PC like me, this is a fun game to pass time in (assuming you don't want to play GTA IV, of course...)

For a f2p mmo such as this, the gameplay is quite enjoyable. Though the story takes a small while to warm up, after players get to know the UI to a reasonable level the game becomes slightly addictive. Cooperative class building, equipment crafting and missions make for an enjoyable experience as you and your friends explore new environments.   The only issue I had is late game when pvp gets involved. The terrirotrial resource war pvp becomes very demanding on computer performance. Though not a game breaking issue, folks without gaming towers will just have to stick with pve (which isn't really a bad thing).
Tons of fun, once you get past the learning curve and actually understand the game its awesome. Recommended to play with friends.

Fallen Earth is an entertaining MMORPG set in the apocolyptic future. You play as one of countless clones with an unknown past and future, searching for more than an identity. With countless factions to join, aid, and/or harm, you the player are able to advance and change the storyline of the world. With countless means of combat from guns, explosives, mutations, psionics, and even swords and axes, you can find all a manner of ways to customize your battle experience. With a crafting system that will let you make almost everything in the game as well you can be certain you will almost always be able to make and use anything you find and/or see. The use of third person view for exploration and interaction and first person view for combat may be of some concern for some players, along with the need to explore select areas in groups, but otherwise, the game is easy to get used to and play on your own.

A free gta basically

GTA Online, basically.  Get this game. Mostly due to the fact that it's free to play, but also because its a solid game. It has a lot in common with the extremely popular GTA franchise, with its massive open-world, car stealing, citizen killing and varied weapon selection, but it obviously lacks a coherent story, since it's mostly a Massively Multiplayer Online game, so if you're looking for story, don't try this game. If you're looking for quick fun, action packed gameplay, try it out.   The customization is INSANE in this, you'll probably spend a few hours just to create your character. And the customization doesnt stop here: weapons, clothing (you can customize the clothings, not just what your character is weraing, meaning you can not only change colors but apply designs, logos, emblems, etc on them) and the many vehicles are 100% customizable (and usually upgradable aswell)  Thanks to its random missions and its nice PVP mode, the replayability is extremely high in this game. Just jump in and play.  Graphics 10/10 Soundtrack 9/10 Replayability 14/15 Gameplay 12/15  Overall - 9/10

I have played APB:Reloaded for 4 years total with 2920 hours in game (i dont use steam a whole ton hence ~1k hours.) Great game, great customization. Completely free to play, there is 0 PTW at all. Premium only gives benefits to customization, and aftermatch bonuses. Everything on ARMAS is reskins, early progression, weapon skins, and clothing and vehicle kits. Weapons are well balanced within their niches. Its a little difficult to get a handle on when starting, but find some friends, join a clan, and it becomes a lot better! It has significantly gotten better with the implementation of FairFight (Don't believe most of the claims in chat that someone is 'cheating', most times they actually aren't), and seems that it will only get better.  I recommend this game to players who wish to challenge themselves, can easily learn from their mistakes, and learn from their enemies. As well as players who enjoy customizing their characters, as it has some of the best customization options I have seen in a game so far.  Game also uses a bit of Ram 8gb will do just fine, anything less will probably get frustrating.  See you in San Paro!

This game is probably the best example of Pay 2 Win abominations. While the concept of the game is nice and the gameplay is pretty easy to get used to, it suffers from numerous very serious problems.  Graphics of the game is slightly above average. It doesn't really look bad, but you'll quickly notice that the optimization is rather flawed and the game is unstable and choppy.  When it comes to music, there are several radio stations to listen to, so you could say there's a bit for everyone. Even classical music, which was my personal favorite.  The gameplay itself is okay, but servers often crash and you'll have a hard time finding one that doesn't lag like hell. As I mentioned before, this is pretty much purely a Pay 2 Win game. While you earn some in-game cash to buy yourself new clothes, new cars and other stuff for your 'image', weapons can only be bought for about a week and then they disappear again. So you must either play 24/7 in order to earn enough, or just pay real money for that â¥â¥â¥â¥. And let me tell you - most of those pathetic kids do it. Stuff that you buy with real money is ridiculously overpowered, so you'll just end up angry playing against such no-lifers. The game is also swarmed by cheaters and nobody usually gives a damn about it, so they just keep cheating.  There is no story. You can either play as a cop or as a criminal. You fight each other in a number of game modes. All of them include shooting each other and some include car chases. You get thrown to the game without any tutorial, so you don't know what to do and you must learn the hard way. The community mostly isn't friendly, let alone willing to help you.  The best thing about this game is the customization. There's a wide range of clothes, colors and accessories. You can also create your own decals for both your car and your character. It's also important to mention that you get to create your character before you begin. You can change your face, but also your body. And options here have almost no limits.  What can I say? Despite its great customization options, good concept and fine gameplay, I can't recommend this game. All the fun you can have is quickly ruined by P2W people, cheaters, bad optimization, unstable servers and a very unfriendly community.

With so many hours in the game, I decided that today I will give my conclusion about the game. As you might know, All Points Bulletin: Reloaded is an open-world MMO third person shooter in which two sides, the Enforcers and the Criminals are fighting for control over the city. In my entire gaming career, I haven't seen a game that offers this much customization. From creating symbols like camos, tattoos and logos, to fighting in districts such as Financial(a close quarters combat zone city) and Waterfront(a district mostly for snipers and such), APB Reloaded offers a great experience. Although, bare with me, there are some downsights such as: -Progression will take a long time. It's more like griding if you're the type of guy who cares for the level and the reward. In this case, if you want to spend some money, I recommend Premium. With Premium, you have around 90% more xp and money. -Another thing about Premium is that it allows you to add symbols to your body or clothes up to 50. With f2p, you can add only 3 symbols. -Matchmaking. Oh my god, the matchmaking...  Get ready to fight against maximum threat level enemies. This is still a major problem of the game, since launch. -Some weapons might be overpowered, but there are also weapons for f2p players that are op as well.   Overall, if you are willing to spend some money in the game, I definately recommend it. Playing with friends will bring a much better experince, as any multiplayer/co-op game.

Let me first say that I have several hundred hours from the sandalone version, so I've played more than the 7.9 on my account. The game is fun, it's sort of like a knockoff GTA. You can be a bad guy, rob shops and get into turf wars, do fun violent things, etc. The games biggest benefit, though, is the fact that you can also be a cop. Any cop players who see the criminal players doing bad stuff or doing missions can immediately intervene and **** them up, which makes for some good fun, and fighting real players as cops is a lot more fun than the crappy AI in games like GTA.  However, this game suffers immensely from it's pay-to-win tactics, through which you will dominate all other players if you have $20 to blow. The devs tout your ability to customize your character, despite the fact that if you want to place more than a few decals on your car or make an intricate design on your clothes you again have to pay money. Want one of the good guns? Give us money. Want to use said guns for more than a few days? MORE money. Want to get a decent car? ALL THE MONEY. You want to KEEP that car? Oh baby you know that's only allowed if you want to spend money. 'Wow our game is so cool and free-to-play.'  Honestly if they scrapped all the pay-to-win stuff and just charged $10-$20 for the game, this would be a fantastic game. The core features and physics are strong, the gameplay is fun when you're not being bulldozed by people with expendable income, and the game has tons of variety. But all of these strengths are shadowed by the money-grubbing nature of this game. Until they update to a new engine as they've been promising for a long time, and at least cut back on the pay-to-win features, this game is NOT worth playing.   In my opinion, the devs should just design the game again from the ground up with a new engine and release it as a seperate game at a reasonable price. There's no excuse to not do that.

SOOOOO much wasted potential. This game could have been what GTA online should have been, but too many flaws are holding it back.  The gameplay is very, very fun. Missions have you either breaking into buildings, hijacking cars, or hacking satellites if you are a criminal, or preventing criminals from doing so and arresting people if you are a dirty copper. While most of the time the missions are actually balanced and require strategic plays and superior aiming from both teams, there are plenty of times where mission objectives can be exploited by parking a car on top of the objective and shooting it til it explodes, rendering the mission impossible to complete. Not fair or fun. It is also very likely as a bronze rank you will get stuck against gold ranks with pay2win 1shotkill guns.  Also hackers. So. Many. Hackers. If you somehow manage to make it to gold rank, you will never be in another mission without an aimbotter. You won't. Ever.  Customization is amazing. Everything is customizeable from your character to the car they drive to the song the enemy hears when they kill you. But hackers. Always hackers everywhere aimbots hacks hacking hackers hacked bot botter aimot botting aimbotting hacks

I started playing this game in 2010 (not on Steam, I guess I have less than 300 hours played). It has changed a lot since that time - sound effects have changed, content was added, already existing items and enemies were balanced and, last but not least, the game was sold to another studio. Twice.   The time when RotMG belonged to first one, Wildshadow Studios, was probably the best time of the game. Game was simple and fun to play, Pay to Win almost didn't exist. In 2012 RotMG was sold to Kabam. They made it a bit Pay to Win, they also did nothing aganist hackers. Later, they decided to work on their other games instead of RotMG, but in July 2016 Deca Games bought RotMG - they keep adding new content and events and they finnaly started fighting aganist notifier hackers. Now it's really a good time for the game.  RotMG is a bullet-hell, team MMORPG with A LOT of different items, monsters and dungeons. All 14 classes are available for free (you only need a bit of time to get 'em all) and are almost perfectly balanced. You can play support/dps/tank (often mixed in one character), whatever you want. There's also a possibility of joining a guild consisting of other players. Overall, the game is indrecibly fun to play despite being a bit Pay to Win - there's a perma-death, character loses all of his items upon dying. MMO Dark Souls for free.  You can have a lot of fun playing RotMG, especially with a group friends, or a guild and you don't have to spend a lot of time on it.  8/10 would lose everything again

I dont have that many hours put into APB when I wrote this review. But from the time I've played APB at the lowest graphic settings and with 20 FPS I currently think its a decent game. It IS ONE OF THE FEW games that allow you to customize the absolute hell out of you and your cars. The combat system is OK, although infinite stamina isnt that realistic. 'Headshots' do the same damage on your head and your foot, which disables headshot instakills, sometimes good, sometimes bad.  Now about the buying system in APB. You buy a guy in the game, a decent gun. Do you have it? Yes, for 10 days. ARMAS marktplace, you can buy quite a lot of decent and nice stuff. Like nice packs which can include clothes, weapons, attachments, modifications, vehicles and emotes. BUT the best guns in the game you HAVE to buy with REAL money. Which makes this game lean even more to a P2W. Now if they were to put the best guns and every gun in the in-game shop which you buy with your well earned in-game money AND make them last FOREVER and not for only 10 days. I mean, you dont buy a car IRL to drive 10 days with it and then bring it back to the car dealer, do you? You dont go to the mall to buy some bread, eat it, then crap it out and then bring it back to the mall, do you?  I would give this game a rating of 6.5/10. It has amazing customization, an interesting server setup and a free-roam to mission 'map' but the developers are greedy, very very very very greedy. They want you to BUY somewhat EVERYTHING in the game to keep it FOREVER. Thats not how it works. Not at all.

Such examples will be unstable latency where if you stay in a country far from the server, you will not be able to move your character and shoot smoothly as people who stay in the country that has the server. Another problem is the premium guns where some free-players and beginners will find themselves in a serious disadvantage compared to premium players who has wide range of guns suited to their situations.  APB is one of those games where it feels good to play at first, but as times goes on, you will find yourself in a battle of keeping your interest alive of playing the game.  I give this a 5/10.   -Kiro

Not exactly Grand Theft Auto, but if it was, I wouldn't need to play to find out where it goes. The freedom to roam the streets as either Criminal or Enforcer is enticing, like playing Cops and Robbers except I actually get to riddle them full of holes.  Criminals can keep busy doing all kinds of things, breaking into store fronts and stealing merchandise, mugging people on the street, stealing vehicles and turning them into chop shops for a finders fee, making that money.   Enforcers on the other hand kind of get the short end of the stick. With few opportunities to make money outside of missions, progression obtaining better gear is a good bit longer, but without Enforcers, Criminals would have no one to fight. I think that Enforcers could use a bit more of a pick-me-up.  Guns. Honestly, outside of vehicular manslaughter, this is your only kill option, and frankly, I get bored with just guns. I would love to sneak up behind those Crims and put a blade between their ribs. So many opportunities would have been mine if there were a melee option.  Third person point of view kind of hurts the excitement a little bit, it's difficult to really pinpoint the reason behind it but I always feel a good bit more control in first person perspective.  Driving is a challenge, but I actually like it that way, learning all of the nuances to different vehicles, knowing when to start turning, take your foot off the gas, and put it back on to make that absurd u-turn, all the while laughing because everyone else is smacking into the walls, trying to catch up. Learning curves are sick...  Movement and running are okay, no real complaints, but interacting with the world? Doors, ladders, fences etc. is very primitive. You can Only climb from the bottom of the ladder to the top or vice versa, instead of being able to sit on the ladder from the perfect vantage point and open fire, or waiting for the perfect moment to climb that last rung. The only barriers you can climb over are predesignated chainlink and wooden fences so entries and escapes can only get so creative. Doors, you can only kick, you can't open slowly and maintain anonimity. The worst thing about it all I think, is that your name is brightly displayed over your character, even if only a hair on the top of your head is visible. No sneaking up in this game.  Story? There's supposed to be one, but personally I think it along with the missions and gameplay lack any real depth and character growth. It's basically glorified Team Deathmatch.  Temporary guns. To get anything permanent, takes tons of grinding. I'm not even going to get into this.  Customization? I think that Second Life could have done a lot better if they followed this games rules on customization, giving you basic shapes to work into your own design. This allows for great degrees of creativity, matched with a lack of graphic-produced lag, making for a comparitively fluid, yet personal experience. Just be sure to go into the customization with patience and a solid plan, and it'll come out great.  Pros  Customization Driving challenge Freedom to roam  Cons  Primitive movement Glowing names No melee Lack of depth   I think I'll keep playing on and off because it is a fun game, but I am actively looking for a replacement on my list, so let me call this a tentative recommendation.

Game is hilariously broken. It's fun to play for a few hours while you marvel at the bugs. The 'physics' are absurd and worse than anything I've ever seen in a commercial game with this many players. You can tell they have the basic weighting or friction completely wrong within the few seconds and the masses of most objects are hilarious. Boxes work like baloons, etc.  Also funny is that civilians inside of cars you steal don't actually exist. So once you rip them out of the car they simply stand there and then disappear. You can cancel some actions in odd ways as well. This means you can begin stealing a car, stop stealing it - doing so causes the civilian driving it to disappear.  I find myself not playing the game much because it's more entertaining to see how they messed up things.  Oh look at the ground when you get a chance you'll notice it has lots of weird glitches. They didn't get the shaders for the ground right...

The character build is pretty cool, but beware the fact that you can't change your character, so try not to have the same characters as each other.   Clans are completely pointless. Unless you have a friend-base of 10 people to make a clan with, there's no point.   Missions aren't so bad, but cooperative exploration is amazing in my opinion.  Other than that, it's not a bad game. I wish there were more games like this though

This game has some good ideas, but poor execution. Whilst the ability to customise your character and vehicles along with themes and other things are very nice and have good variety, the controls for the vehicles are poor and tend to feel sluggish. Other problems that hinder it are poor mission opponent matching with it most often resulting in overpowered experienced people against newer, less well equipped people. This also is shown when a Gold Rank player is left to pay on a Bronze level server even when they should not be allowed to since they are far better skilled/equipped than what the server is designed for. Bronze should be for Bronze only, Silver for Silver and Gold for Gold so as to issue the best matching. Another issue that is prevalent is the way characters ranking is scored, quite often I will go Gold Rank after having a good few rounds. However, this will put me against other gold rank people who are leagues ahead in equipment and skill and leave me feeling frustrated as I lose due to being put against an opponent that is clearly too high a skill level for my own skills. Also seen whilst playing is the way the pay to play aspect causes imbalance in equipment levels. Whilst I do want to pay toward keeping such an interesting game alive, I feel it would be unfair to the other free to play players as I would then gain access to guns and equipment that are far better than anything F2P can access without having to grind multiple days worth of time to get close to having something similar. This is a clear example of Pay to Win. Finally, and most importantly, along with being the worst point against this game, there are just too many cheaters that uses hacks on this game, it's a well known issue but in the whole time playing this game, nothing has been done to stop it. Too often has it been the case I've gone to verse a team of criminals that quite clearly have players that are using hackers to boost there accuracy or take less damage when shot. This is quite obvious when you are two shot killed by a shotgun or pistol more than 100m from your opponent or open fire on said opponent first but discover that even after multiple direct hits they will kill you in three shots.  Overall, a nice concept with some good ideas but poorly executed with too many bugs and hackers.

Fallen Earth is a post-apocalyptic game with sci-fi technology. It was released September 22, 2009 and with that said... Making a game with let's just go with a major title, CoD or Battlefield like graphics...It'd need a engine to process it and this is a game already finished. So the graphics are dated, even at it's highest setting can look like a mudded mess.  You know what, no, no, I wanted to be a bit nice to this game. Look at my screenshots. The mane of my horse, a free mount is beyond s***. Hell my shadow while in first person is cut in half at the waist, and there's no first person animations what so ever. There are in third, but that is just horrid. If that isn't bad enough you get spells and skills like in World of Warcraft..I'm playing at max settings mind you. There are no animations, effects, nothing like that for anything you use in first person. So I don't know if I'm using a poison spell or a spell that s***s f***ing rainbows. Should I mention if I try to heal while in combat that I'll actually heal my enemy? WHAT!?! Oh yes, you have to TARGET yourself to HEAL yourself.  This game is a hardcore knock off of Fallout 3 and New Vegas. The graphics are the same if not worse then both, huge lack of animations, glitches, and just awful, dreadfully poor, sloppy and LAZY design work. If that doesn't p*** you off then what about the fact you have to swap from mouse to aim every 2 minutes to click on a quest, item, object, whatever it be..Ending tutorials, etc.. Oh your mouse cursor is what they use as the game cursor. That's just f***ing pathetic work.   Another fun thing is crafting, and timers. They haven't yet, but I'm damn sure a single timer can easily eventually be an hour if not longer. By the way you can only craft ONE, ONE ITEM AT A TIME IF you do not buy their stupid VIP. Want more, I've yet to go into PvP and frankly I don't think I want to with the other reviews I've read. Already see paid content is able to move ridiculously faster, and it seems at best if you don't pay for the game you're getting a horse. My mind is just blown. That's just mounts/vehicles...What about these keys and boxes and crap that give amazing gear you CANNOT GET ANYWHERE ELSE?! No. Just no. It figures, any title under 'GamersFirst' is nothing but a pryamid scheme for your money. I'm dead serious too, look at APB: Reloaded and APB.  Oh and the learning curve on this game might as well be a f***ing mountain flying in the air. If it wasn't for having looked at my keybinds, and even then I'd be having difficulty as hell. Don't forget, no animations, effects, etc. with most spells/skills/s***s/f***s I don't give about! The game is about you though and the other 20 or so people around, you died at the Hoover Dam and now you're a clone. Should I mention everyone here and everywhere else f***ing hates clones? You might as well be a Jew in NAZI Germany. Question, what game allows jumping that can't allow turning while in mid-air? Answer, Fallen Earth. S*** YOU NOT. The map could be really big, the thing is though... I DON'T HAVE THE F***ING ABILITY TO SCROLL AROUND THE MAP.  3/10 I will never recommend playing this game, even to see if it's really that bad. It's worse.

In this review I will go over the basic gameplay and explain the Pro and Cons to this game. For a shorter review scroll to the bottom and read the summery.  APB is a MMO third person shooter based on the idea of Cops vs Criminals. Players queue for matches in district servers to do mini pvp matches against each other which take place in various parts of the map. There are 2 'PVE' maps and 2'PVP maps currently. The two PVE maps are the Finacial and Waterfront, each hold their own factions alliances in the district. Players either pledge to a specific contact to level up their standing with them or just play at random leveling up whoever is available.   Both Criminals and Enforcers (Cops) get their own specific gameplay that they can do while in the game. Criminals can operate burgleries by ramming into stores and storage units to steal the items inside,or robbing civilians on the street, then fence the items at their closest contact. Once the items are turned in the criminals are then required to go to the 'Money Launder' to collect the cash. Enforcers can participate in this as well, it is called 'Wittness Mode'. While a Enforcer is driving about he can patrol for Criminals commiting crimes and when he finds them he presses the Wittness Key, default Alt, and him and the criminal are now put into a mission where the Enforcer needs to get the evidence to the lock up while the Criminal needs to get it to the fence. This is a very unique system that is very entertaining and always present in the game. Enforcers also get a unique gameplay choice which is Less Than Lethal weapons. LTL weapons are the games way of making it more interesting and putting a twist on the game. When using LTL weapons, the Enforcer stuns the enemy and then arrests the Criminal. Criminals are able to free their team mates from handcuffs but only if they can make it there in time. The advantage to LTL is it makes the spawn timer longer, with the disadvantage that the LTL have a shorter range and require time to arrest Criminals putting the Enforcer in danger of enemy fire.  Being that the game is a third person shooter, the game is less about skill and more about placement. Covering corners and knowing the range of your weapons as well as how they fire can give you a large advantage over players who are simply pointing and shooting. The starting rifle both Crims and Enforcers start with is incredibly good, both in accuracy and power but it must be fired with control burst instead of full auto otherwise it loses it's strengths. That being said the game is incredibly unfriendly to new players, it has such a large learning curve that it causes most people to give up and stop playing. Because of that the playerbase is reletively smaller and all the players tend to merge into the 'Silver' districts which can cause unfair match making. New players should be recomended to play on the 'Bronze' servers until they learn the ropes better and are ready for the big servers.  One of the biggest gripes about the game is the cash shop, yes the cash shop sells weapons. Before you drop the game though you should know the weapons in the cash shop have very little difference compared to the 'free' weapons. Most CS weapons are infact reskins of the free ones, with the exception of the few that are special/unique weapons. One of the most powerful weapons in the game is also one of the first ones you unlock for free. Most of what comes out of the cash shop is cosmetic items that are for cars and clothes.  So now that we went over the basics and you have a little bit of an understanding of what you are getting into, lets get into the good things about this game. Number one of all time is, the customization. Free players are limited on how much customization they can do in the game, but even then I've seen amazing things come from free people. You can style everything from the clothes you wear to the logos on them, from the tattoos on your body to how fat you want to be. Customize your car, it's color, the model, the decals, the lisence plate, body kits, even interior design on some of them. Your weapons can be modifide depending if you unlocked guns with open mod slots. Do you like your gun shooting faster, more accurate, longer range, better zoom, better hipfire, bigger magazine, or maybe you like to carry more ammo. You can use mods to change that. Even with your car too, Nitro, Steel plating, mobile spawn, mobile ammo supply, or even have a brick that can be used when you jump out of your car to launch it at enemy players. Players can add mods to their character as well to carry ammo, be able to survive hits from vehicles, reduce fall damage, or even ride ontop of cars without falling off. The game has endless combinations and possiblities that you can take advantage of and have fun with.  The conclusion, if you can get around the very steep learning curve, get over the cash shop selling weapons and just have fun with the game, you will enjoy it. This game is one of the few games where customization is literally at your command. Dress as a business man, or run around half naked, it's your choice. Alter your weapons to your play style and make your dream car, it's all in your hands. The game is definately worth a try for people who like shooters, but remember that the game can put you in unfair match making at times. This is because of the size of the playerbase, the more people play the better match making gets. Those of you who just read the bottom and are thinking of trying the game, I suggest you give the whole review a once over to understand what I'm talking about completely and half some understanding of what you are going to be doing ingame.

QUICK RANT, PROS+CONS BELOW  The game is good, really good. I love it. BUT SWEET MOTHER OF GOD DOES PUNKBUSTER SUCK â¥â¥â¥â¥. 1st hour of 'playtime' - trying to get Punkbuster (APB's anti-cheating system) to work and not throw errors in my face; 2nd hour and the first half of the 3rd hour - having extreme fun, loving the game so much; the rest of my 'Playtime' - trying to get Punkbuster to work again, but I give up.  I really don't know why any game uses Punkbuster. From my experience, all games with Punkbuster have extreme amounts of bullcrap regarding being able to play (APB just confirms that once more). I'd love to recommend this game, but hell, I barely got to play it. And I will definitely not waste more time on it.  Pros+  *Really fun to play, there is just so much freedom *Has that GTA 5 feel to it - not exactly it, but something of it's own *Obtaining standart currency (cash) is pretty easy, fast and painless, so it shouldn't take you more than a couple hours (MAX) to obtain a new piece of gear *The difference between being a premium or free player is simply progression speed - and both are pretty close together to each other  Cons-  *As stated in my rant, it uses the Punkbuster anti-cheat. It throws up so many false flags that it's even pepe-worthy. That'd would be a really â¥â¥â¥â¥in rare pepe tho...I gotta make that now *Some guns are just straight up better than others, and there's nothing you can do (only exception being your and your enemy's reaction times - that alone can sometimes kill you or the enemy) *It appears that headshots are not a thing in this game. Heads have no model, so good aim isn't rewarded all that much. As an FPS vet, this seems really weird to me  CONCLUSION  This game is great beyond 'it shows potential', it is so much fun even if you're alone (with friends, it is CONSIDERABLY more fun though), but Punkbuster and some minor balance issues are holding this game down. If you have a pretty good computer and Punkbuster doesn't drown you in errors, I can GUARANTEE you'll enjoy this game (at the very least).

I have been playing APB reloaded on and off steam for a while. I will state the following:   PROS:   If you enjoy enhanced character customization and opposing enemy players in non-stop PVP this game is for you. The detail of character customization, Vehicle customization, Clothing retexture is abundant, Moreso than most MMO's I've ever played. atleast one server seems to be densely populated at all hours of the day, There are always players online. You get a fully customizable soundtrack to play from your vehicle. The open world crimes and witness events give the game play immersion.  CONS: There are hackers who use aimbot sometimes, Allthough most get banned with the new anti-cheat system some bypass it or return on a fresh account. When you're a low level in the bronze district as bronze threat level, Gold threat level players equipped with preimum gear will camp you and kill the crap out of you, you'll be lucky to last five seconds without being picked off after respawn in some matches. As far as the community is concerned, Like most MMOs or FPS's Such as Call of duty or WoW, Players can be really disrespectful via district chat or mic, predictably Some can be very cancerous and toxic with thier insults and PM's, These players are usually team killers and generally will try to bring down the whole team, Not that I care but people who aren't like me who aren't desensitized to it will. Not that i'm sure it matters in this type of game, But there is no RPG element to the game, You'd have to think, There are NPC interactions in this game verbal and physical, Mugging, Diolouge, Contacts, Mail from contacts. Why is there no NPC missions or PVE? I'd probably play this game A lot more if it did have an RPG element to it and Solo missions. Sometimes I don't want to PVP, the same routine kind of gets boring after a short wile.  Conclusion: Despite the cons, I'd still reccomend APB reloaded. After all it is ranked #1 in most top 10 character generation videos, I have a lot of fun doing open world crime or when on my enforcer arresting players who commit crimes. The game itself is more adult oriented and more to my level of prefrence, Something you rarely see at all in today's games.

This game has it's fair share of issues... It's one of those 'Pay to Win' games with korean style web-browser RMT-shop. Hackers run rampant and even if you manage to play with legit players, you will be (Seriously, you WILL be. Matchmaking sucks due to low player population and crappy code) decimated by them because they are far more experienced and better geared than you. Also, you will get against clans a lot, so prepare for that if you are ever going to give this game a shot. It's buggy, it feels cheap, missions get repetitive after a while and everything sucks.  Well, not everything. I enjoyed thoroughly the many customization options APB has. Sticking decals to yourself and to your car is more fun than it seems at first. You also could do even your own songs and 'themes' using an ingame music studio. But don't get too excited, you are not going to be able to explore all of it - some extremely useful features are locked behind a paywall.  Bottom line: Unless you are ready to pay for 'premium' - membership (Yeah, this game has a 'subscription', by subscribing, you can get your hands on more content which you cannot access as a normal player) and for some OP-weapons (Which can cost as much as 40 - 60â¬ and more EACH) , don't buy this game. In my opinion, there are better things (GAMES) to spend your money on.

Let me start off with the word: 'wow...'  This game has stolen so much out of my time. But in the good way of course!  I have played APB: R for a COUNTLESS amount of hours. I met tons of nice people, that I eventually have become really good friends with outside the game.   The game has TONS of customization and replay value. The missions start getting repetitive, but the players and the gameplay of the different players make it so much different every time. I love it!  The game runs smoothly, but you do need a bit of a strong PC to play it. If you have problems over steam, I would suggest you to download the standalone from Gamersfirst themselves and add  APB Advanced Launcer  [forums.gamersfirst.com]  to it. It allows you with tons of more customization for your graphical settings than the game can give you. Props to the guy who made it!  Rounding up, 9/10. The game has its flaws, but I love the game with them. It wouldn't be the same fun without them! Cheers Gamersfirst for picking up a dead game and making it free to play! (the game died after a subscription model, but got brought up again)

Now I know my hours of gameplay for this game doesn't say much, but hear me out anyways.  APB:R is an open world MMO where the players could either be the criminals or the enforcers. The roles are quite self-explainatory   The gameplay itself is quite what you would expect from any other third-person game, run to cover, peep out, unload your guns, that or you could just jump out and spray your munition and pray that it lands on the target. The gameplay however isn't what fascinates me, it is the customization option that you apply to your ride or your player model. You can create your very own designs from scratch, whether or not it ends up as tattoo or a car decal, the endless possiblity of creation is simply just mind blowing (Provided that you unlock all the customization option). As someone who studies graphic designs, this is my nice cup of tea.   Note: Premium players can put in more customization items on their clothings/car/tattoos compared to f2p players.  Of course, since this is a free to play game there are in-game items that you can buy to give you an edge against your opposition. Personally however, I think this game is still reasonable even if you are a f2p player.  The only downside for me is probaly the community inside the game. I'm not sure about the other servers, but the server I'm currently residing in is just..just.... full of twelve years old who are uncapable of listening to reason and logic. Oh yeah. When I saw this game, I expected to be somewhat of a DayZ experience to the extent that other players would be trying to kill you. I was very wrong in this assumption.   It turns out that the only enemies are the npcs. Speaking of npcs, they aren't even ok. All they do is walk around in a ten inch radius and will only attack you if you shoot at them or get really really close. Even if you're like three feet in front of their face, they will not attack you.    The weapon switch is also very finnicky. It took me five minutes just to get my character to dual wield. (that was either the game or just my lack of a good mouse   If you are looking for a game that has just an ok gameplay, I would bring this one up. But if you want a good survival game with good fighting and gameplay, do NOT get this one.

The game has potential but like so many other Free-To-Play games it suffers from poor performace, Pay-To-Win players, and several game breaking bugs such as exploitable invisible walls and suceptibility to aim-bots amongst other hacks. The game has so much potential to be fun, and to make the dev's money if they would just put in the effort to make the game fair and balanced. The matchmaking system is broken as well. The district you choose is supposed to match you against equally skilled opponents, but in a world full of hacks cheats and obnoxious children this hardly makes a difference. You will get matched up against pros every time because they are the only players left as the new players get scared away by everything I just mentioned.
If you like rocketlauncher battle world, you will like it. If you don't, then don't download this game. It's just a pay 2 win with brainless kids.
Free 2 play pay 2 win game

This was a tough one to recommend or not, but I'm going to have to go with no. I wanted to say yes, and I would have, only if the Devs paid more attention to newer people who play the game for the very first time. I will first start off with a Pros/Cons list  Pros:  Decent Graphics HUGE map Good combat (not just point in click, you actually have to aim and shoot) Factions is a neat idea ontop of clans PvP is for the most part, actually about skill Lots of things to do at max level  Cons:  HUGE map, but not much in it Melee is SO overpowered Can't trust faction members, you have half chance of them betraying you Not nearly enough support at lower levels (will explain later) Rude community GM's don't do much Horrible customer support (will explain later)  Now, when I say 'Not nearly enough support at lower levels' I mean that there has been so many updates in the game to keep higher level'd people to keep playing, example, the G.O.R.E. update (that whole update was a mess), while there's no updates or anything for lower level'd people, the game has a decent tutorial system, but just like anything, a tutorial can only help so much, you actually need to do it to get better. If you want to craft, you need to scavenege in PvP areas for certain things and people usually just camp there waiting for people to show up to get stuff to craft and waste them before they even know what happens. The economy is pretty messed up, ammo, which costs nothing to make really, is sold for a pretty pricey amount, I understand supply and demand but holy crap, it's hard to get money as a lower level so ammo isn't going to be cheap for them.  Customer support... It literally means 'customer support' if you're a f2p, they don't give a flying â¥â¥â¥â¥ about you, (it's kind of like TF2, if you buy a single item from the online store, you unlock things, such as no money limit and all that), in fact, unless you bought something or have a subscription, you can't even file a ticket! Even people who are paying a montly fee for the game, they barely care about you. GM's hardly do anything to help you, but they do throw bans left and right on a power hungry trip. The community is rude, 80% of the people there are the ones who have still played when the game is P2P so they thing they're better than everyone in general.  As for factions, there are Techs, Travelers, Light Bearers, Enforcers, CHOTA and I forget what the last one is called, they're kind of like hippies, anyways, each one has a natural ally and a natural enemey, Techs hate the hippies, but Techs are allied with Travelers, but Travelers hate Light Bearers, etc etc, but unfourtantely none of that matters since if you if you're a Traveler, you'll get freaking shot up by another Traveler, otherwise the whole faction thing would be an awesome idea.  I really liked the game at first, but it kept going downhill, the last thing I will say is the G.O.R.E. update, it released new weapons, a rifle, pistol and sword. Each one of those weapons were able to be upgraded 2 times, so it'd be rifle, upgraded rifle, upgraded upgraded rifle, but of course, each upgrade was harder to do, and the most upgraded rifle, could easily one hit kill someone, the DPS on the pistols (which shot in three burst (now fixed)) was insanely high, and well, for the sword, all melee is over powered so you get the idea on that. Some people made a clan to nerf the guns, some people made a clan to get rid of the update and killed anyone (the clan was always in a zerg) using the weapons, whether they were in the same faction or not. And then there was a clan that said to keep the update as is, and of course, they were using the Level 3 weapons. So they finally nerfed the weapons after about a month or so. Some people are wondering things like 'Why is he even saying this?' Well, I'm saying this because if the Devs released an update that had insanely OP weapons without even thinking about if it's OP, or to test it or anything really, It really makes me not being able to trust them with future content, and also, the only reason the nerfed it, is because people were canceling their subscriptions until they nerfed it  Edit: Typos and added a statement in the 'Customer Support' part

This game is NOT noob friendly. in APB reloaded, there is no sign of matchmaking whatsoever. it just compiles a random clusterâ¥â¥â¥â¥ of people to duke it out. which means if you're just starting out, you could easily be placed against someone who's been playing nonstop for months repeatedly. I tried to get on my feet in that game for 3 days, but every cent I earned went toward ammo or was lost in deaths to people who play nonstop and pay actual money for the good equipment.   also, I dare say that this is the single most infuriating game I have ever played. even more so than Call of Duty. I don't get angry easily, but this game angered me to the point where I threw my mouse across the room and shattered the damn thing. So, here's a warning. if you're angered easily, AVOID APB RELOADED  It's a shame, because the idea behind it had a lot of potential. I was really excited to see someone finally making a game like this where you could actually be the cop with custom cars and weapons. It had so much potential, but the absolutely terrible matchmaking and blatantly obvious pay to win strategy ruined the entire thing for me.  long story short: unless you're willing to spend an untold amount of hours on this game, all it's going to do is infuriate you. it's a gigantic avoid from me.

After playing this game for more than 15oo hours, none-steam and spending 500$. one day upon logging in I get disconnected and the ban hammer fell on me, after contacting support and meeting a bot called Dastard who kept sending me the same and same response, I lost all hope of getting unbanned and decided to take my revenge by writing this review, donât get me wrong Iâm not actually going to bash the game or lie about it, just the plain truth coming from a guy who used to have 2 gold max ranks. This game has many glitches, its p2w not f2p, and there are a lot of cheaters. I personally could cope with the bugs, glitches and its p2win-ness. Sometimes can say I enjoyed them, found them funny, but the main thing that makes you want to rip your own eyes out is cheaters. Well on that subject, there are three types of cheaters, first we have low rank blatant cheaters who are really easy to identify and are banned in a couple of days, and then we have high level (mostly gold max ranks) closet cheaters that are unnaturally good and you just canât get to kill them. When you confront them, they say we are pro or we have ts or blah blah â¦ sometimes you can see some of them who got caught on  ffbans.org . Now the third and the most annoying ones are whitelisted cheaters, G1 actually knows that these people are cheating hard but doesnât do anything just because they pay them a lot of money and if you dare report them, they ban you instead. Call me a conspiracy theorist or nuts, this has happened to people I knowâ¦ they caught these people cheating on video and reported them and those legit guys got banned after 3-4 days âDUE TO CHEATINGâ themselvesâ¦ coincidence right ??? so in conclusion, unless you are a masochistic I donât recommend this fail excuse of a game.

I have mixed feelings about APB. I appreciate that it's not another WoW-copy-paste McDonalds MMO, but I feel that some basic design decisions really hold this game back from being anything but frustrating. First of all, no story. I have no motivation to do squat in this game, other than 'just to kill people and get upgrades'. Second: pure PvP, and VERY imbalanced at that. There is no 'PvE' to speak of, and the PvP is absolutely lopsided, due in no small part to being able to BUY better weapons at EXORBENT prices. Almost all missions are PvP based, and the group finder has no problem pitting 2 players against 1, or 7 against 3 as I repeatedly whitnessed. There are just enough players PAYING for weapons to make most missions total blow-outs, absolutely unentertaining especially with the rediculously long respawn timer AND distance they put you away from the objectives. You spend more time waiting and traveling than playing the game. One hesitant thumb up, and one way down.  I've learned from APB and Dungeons and Dragons Online that I really do not enjoy the F2P model whatsoever. Either players are given rediculous advantages in gameplay (which breaks PvP games like this) or content restriction provides a lonely, frustrating game where the players are segergated by different levels of content access, as in the case of DDO.

If you have some friends to play with, APB Reloaded gives one many hours of great gameplay. Unfortunately some decisions from the developers give a hint that developers' name 'Gamersfirst' leads to a false point of view.

This game has really great atmosphere. That is because most of the content is ripped straight from the Wasteland/Fallout universe. If you ever wanted to play a Fallout-ish MMO, this is the best choice. It's more focused on crafting and the whole 'carrot on the stick' gameplay, and of course you can just buy the carrot. I really enjoyed the short time I spent in game.  I'm torn about this game because, quite frankly, the community is just awful. Instead of Zone chat like in most mmo's, there's a Help chat. It's filled with players that have been there for a while, but most of them have that whole 'elite' attitude. Help chat is supposed to be used for people with questions, thus the name. These 'Elitists' will use Help chat for anything they want, berate and accuse new players of trolling, then turn around and lecture everyone on the 'proper way' to use Help chat. The GM's are even worse. They constantly hand out mutes/bans, but ignore any complaints towards the preffered players that have been there for a long time or spent probably $500 in the cash shop.   Also, the GM's are crazy about censoring peoples' screen names. I had a name that wasn't even offensive, I played for a bit and when I came back, my name was Cupcake1244. Yes, if they deem your name offensive, you get to roam the Wastelands as Cupcake____. And you only get 1 character slot as a F2P player. I contacted a GM about changing my name and guess what? Oh, you can BUY a name change in the cash shop. $10 because you got offended for no reason? Hah!  Unfortunately, I'm the type of person that's going to argue right back with you when you're acting douchey. So I told everyone off in Help chat and am uninstalling :)   To sum it up, if you enjoy the crafting side of mmo's with a Fallout/Wasteland atmosphere, go for it. But if you're not going to spend money on it, I'd suggest that you keep the chat window closed and just chat with people locally. You're going to want to avoid these Basement-Dwellers.

After playing this game for 1 year, I can honestly say that I am sick of it. In the beginning, I really enjoyed the game, simply for the fact that it was basically an online version of GTA (open world, stealing pedestrian cars, shooting, third person, etc). The customization in the game was what also kept me drawn to it (also because it is a third person shooter). The amount of detail you can put on your character was like no other F2P game that I have played. Plus you have the ability to create unique custom symbols, themes, songs and car designs. The gameplay is also pretty good. The missions are standard (pick up items, guard items, capture and hold the base/item). It's kinda cool how even though you are in a mission, you are still in the open world and still able to interact with others outside the game (like you don't have to go in a game room and have private matches). But it also gets annoying to deal with grievers and having players run into each other.   Of course with any PVP game, you will have players who are more skilled in the game than others. That's the reason for the player threat level (Bronze, Silver and Gold). There are districts for each of these levels, but of course players choose to play in the lowest district threat as they could (Gold players in Silver district and Silver players in Bronze district). I'm not complaining though because I am just as guilty of this (we all like to feel pro ^^). The weapons in the game however can be unbalanced. Those who choose to purchase G1C have the fortune of obtaining the latest (and most garbage looking reskins remade with some percs) weapons. But that's nothing new. Every game has it's share of P2W.  What I hated most about this game was the community. I haven't played much online games in general, but with the few that I have, it does not compare to the level of displeasure as APB.Of course with any online game, you get your share of trolls, douches and jerks; but this game somewhat gives the advantage to these people (for example: following you around with a car to grieve you, ghost your missions, or sit on top of mission items to purposely make you lose a mission). Not to mention if you are having some luck on a day and do exceptionally well in your matches, you are then insulted and accused of hacking. In opposition to that, if you do poorly you are also ridiculed for playing as an amateur and labelled as a 'noob' or 'scrub'. So no matter how good or bad you are at this game, you will face some form of harassment.  So like I said, I have developed an extreme dislike for this game. Or maybe I've been playing it for too long and finally become sick of it. It's still a fun game, even if it has it's MAJOR flaws.

APB Reloaded is an Open World, GTA-like, cops vs robbers style MMOTPS. You get to rent cars and weapons for 10 days minimum or buy them permanently from their overpriced store with real money; then you get to customise those cars with parts you earn doing missions or if it's bought from the overpriced store. You can also customise your characters extensively, dye clothes, design patterns, use them on your clothes or even on your character as tattoos or just add them to your vehicle. About the gameplay: it's purely PVP, meaning you will be fighting against other players, you will either have a lot of fun or get pissy for being accused of hacking/name calling, but that's a bit normal for PVP isnt it. All that being said, game still has some bugs and an imbalanced system that sometimes favour one side more than the other, not to mention the 'pay4win' thing, the overpriced and overpowered market weapons and such. Despite everything the game is quite fun and the best in its genre.

This game is extremely addicting and fun, the first few hours are boring but once you get past that this game is AMAZING. Graphics are meh and the combat system is kinda bad, however the simple fact that I can go into a cave mine some coal kill giant ants and underdwellers to find a secret cavern is just awesome. And th MMO part adds so much immersion to the game, know whats more fun than attacking a bandit camp? Attacking it with a group of people. I normally stray away from games like this but I have been playing this bad boy nonstop. Also notice how most of the bad reviews complain about difficulty or buggyness or complicated gameplay yet they haven't played for more than 10 hours? They say some crap like this game is Pay2win, and its not at all, Sure paying gets you some 'new' things faster but you can get most of these things ingame anyway. If you are a realism fan then get this game. Note this game has a big learning curve and difficulty spike.  Now to the problems The enemy AI tends to be â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥, Enemy's respawn in 1 minute taking away from immersion, for some reason the damage and health system is bad (No joke dogs do 20 Dmg a bite and attack every seconds or so and I've gotton surrounded by em and killed in seconds as the â¥â¥â¥â¥â¥ take bullets to the head) Stay away from junkyward dogs and gurad dogs is my only tip, The scavenging system can be quite stupid sometimes as well.   Over all this game has +Great gameplay mechanics +Interesting storys and characters +Great immersion +Addictive micro managing +Great trade and communication system  The middle ground Game lacks mercy for new player which can drive people away but not a problem and is more made for intense gamers, not bad but not great graphics.  Now the bad  -Terrible AI -Unhelpful NPC's -Strange level system -Fast enemy respawns  Overall I'd give this game a 8.9/10

APB Reloaded seems to be a good idea on paper. What is that idea? Make an online multiplayer game that somewhat seems to be based off of GTA. Does this idea work? I'd say it's a tad mix of both 'yes' and 'no'.  To begin, you can choose from two 'factions' and these are the criminals and the police. The criminals commit crimes and work together to cause as much chaos as possible. These can be as simple as stealing a car and ramming over many pedestrians or working together to rob stores and escape. Eventually, you will cause enough trouble and then you will become a target for the cops (who happen to be controlled by other players). While creating chaos can be fun, I found myself working alone and seeing many other criminal players doing the same thing. I hardly saw two criminals working together during my playtime. Being a target for the cops isn't much fun either as the main goal for the cops seemed to be just finding you and killing you. They don't try to arrest you or anything of the sort; they just chase you and bring you down with bullets. After you die, you just respawn and do it all over again. There are some sort of missions in the game but I wasn't given the slightest clue to where they were. I found a suitcase and was told to deliver it to some location but don't expect the map to get you anywhere as it wasn't much for help.  After derping around with the criminal faction I played the cop faction. Problem is, I found difficulty in even finding my way out of the spawn area and, as stated before, the map isn't much for help. My best guess is that the cop faction patrols the city area and is given a list of target criminals to find and gun down.  Here's a short list of pros and cons that include some points that were not covered: + Vehicles handle differently in an appropiate manner + Graphics look fairly good + Creating chaos is enjoyable + Fair amount of character and vehicle customization + Basic free roaming is entertaining - Map is hard to deal with - Difficult to find missions - Little teamwork - Slight lag issues - Police only shoot down criminals - Community is known to be a little less than friendly  Eventually the confusion and constant deaths bored me and I can't recommend this game to anyone. It'll be nice to uninstall this game to make room for a more deserving one.

APB:R - What can i say? 1: It's the best game i've ever played. 2: It's the worst game i've ever played.  The good:  - First its a fun F2P game.  - Once you get use to the driving in the game cars can be really fun and you and your friends can setup waypoints around the map and race. - The game stops most hacks. Though the game still can't seem to stop some aimbots and macro's. Many cheats in other games on offer are simply not on offer because the servers are hosted by GamersFirst. This means no annoying speed hacks/GodMode/Etc. - No other game can offer you this much customization. You can make your charatcer look like anything you can think of. From 'Ronald Macdonald' to the 'Joker (Batman)' Any of this is possible. You can customize your cars and even make some crazy tattos. - The game unlike Call Of Duty. Requires a lot of teamwork. So i strongly advise grouping up with some friends. You can all work together using different guns so you run up to a enemy with a Shotgun whilst your teammate covers you from a far with a sniper.  The bad: - I have simply never played a game what is so demanding. By far it isn't the best looking game but you can play Battlefield 3 or Skyrim on High FPS but You probably won't be able to play APB at 60FPS without it dropping to 40 or less. - The servers. They suck. Thats all i can say. - Like many F2P there is some P2W in it. If you want to invest a little real money in APB it costs a lot just to get a perm gun for your account ($30+). The guns aren't really P2W. Most of them are just reskins of guns you can unlock in game without paying real money. - This game isn't Noob friendly. Many new players join expecting to play another noob. Well guess what its a either a pro whos created a new account or a decent player who has decided to dethreat so they can stomp on the poor noobs. - They constantly bring new things out. What pretty much always cost you real money.  Conclusion: Get the game its free try it out. When you first get it you probably will get your â¥â¥â¥ kicked all the time. Just chill and carry on playing. When you hit around 50hours playtime you'll be a good driver. Have some cool stuff unlocked and will be winning a few mission =)  Rating 7.5/10

I've played this game extensively before it came to Steam. If you're looking for a F2P version of GTA, this isn't it. Move along, nothing to see here.  It's not a bad game but it shouldn't be taken seriously. It's rife with hackers, griefers and players who will 'ghost' you during missions. You won't be able to kill them and they can follow you around, distract you, block your objectives, ram your vehicle and tell their allies exactly where you are.  The cash shop in this game is ridiculous. It's like Korean MMO-worthy. One gun can cost you $60 and that's just for a single gun. The monetization doesn't stop there...not on your life and it's incredibly Pay2Win as well.  Now, I know I was just complaining about how the game is full of griefers but to be honest that's really the most fun aspect of the game...doing stuff like taking 4 dumptrucks and blocking off a major highway or parking outside a car garage, leaving a little open space for cars to get through...and when they try to get through...moving in their way as they angrily yell at your immovable dumptruck, causing them to spend more money to re-spawn their vehicle elsewhere.  If you play the game with that kind of attitude, just messing around and having fun...it's not bad. But if you try to play the game seriously, you'll get punked out everytime by either hackers (which run rampant and unchecked) or people who have spent hundreds in the cash shop...or both.
